title: Development Thoughts
text: development project inspired problem organizing many different hypotheses writing thesis. several data sets many, many models, trouble store recall . wanted easier way pull thoughts together, creating dynamic structure unfold along research project . structure, still iterated, easy--understand interface allows following major concepts: Identifying core data queried specific hypothesis Ability handle grouping/strata data subsets analyses Forming hypotheses multiple outcomes multiple predictors epidemiological angle (e.g. exposures, outcomes, covariates) Running updating tests data changes Extracting recalling models research project progresses minimally-experienced programmer, used examples current effective packages designing API. features found missing ability handle variety formulas specific pre-defined hypotheses, focus compare combine models, instead considering focus causality. title: Development Thoughts
text: ’ve currently defined basic functions : octomod() initializes modeling structure core() defines core data octomod structure, allowing tests performed centralized data set arm() creates individual arms octomod, reference specific family hypotheses equip() gives arms tidied output including model fit parameters, can subsequently called benefits can flexibly change core data, give specific formulas can expanded/varied, fit independently, extracted list-column based format. problems “changing” central dataset dangerous, structure doesn’t hold together afterwards, fitting data may break older models.

title: Development Thoughts
text: described, name helps determine function’s purpose. core functions represent major user-facing features. also help identify underlying structure needed store data collected. project() initializes structure holds can retain information individual project aims study arms set_data() attaches specific data frame project object add_arm() creates hypothesis-driven series tests around formula, allows multiple tests described simultaneously (e.g. sequential addition covariates) build_models() runs tests, whether basic statistics complex inferential models, capacity update newly added arms collect_findings() recalls information project structure flexible way

title: Forging many models together
text: package simple use. First, lets load basic packages. mtcars dataset serve example, use linear regressions primary test.
code: library(volundr) #> Loading required package: vctrs #> Loading required package: arcana #> Loading required package: tibble #>  #> Attaching package: 'tibble' #> The following object is masked from 'package:vctrs': #>  #>     data_frame library(parsnip)

title: Subgroup Forest Plot — tbl_forest
text: Subgroup Forest Plot

title: Subgroup Forest Plot — tbl_forest
text: x Class forge object models fit formula Identifies relationships interest, LHS representing outcome, RHS representing exposure. vars Character vector variables interest. can either grouping variables, can performed interaction terms (based models included originally). parameter interaction changed TRUE, create joint confidence intervals presence absence interaction term. interaction Logical value identify model attempt use interaction terms . Currently accepts binary/dichotomous variables interaction term. columns Additional columns help describe subgroup models. least one column selected list. sequence listed #'   reflect sequence shown table. current options : beta = point estimate value, odds ratio hazard ratio conf = inclusion confidence interval (presumed 95%-ile) n = number observations model group example: list(beta ~ "Hazard", conf ~ "95% CI" n ~ ".")" flip Determine odds hazard ratio shown reciprocal values. Instead decreasing hazard every unit increase, describes increasing hazard every unit decrease. axis Argument help modify forest plot . list-formula following parameters. named, function attempt "guess" optimal parameters. options : title = label title column describing forest plot lim = x-axis limits breaks = x-axis tick marks break points numbers int = x-axis intercept lab = label x-axis scale = defaults continuous, may also use log transformation well c("continuous", "log") example: list(title ~ "Decreasing Hazard", lab ~ "HR (95% CI)) width Describes width column list two-sided formulas. RHS decimal reflecting percent column take entire table. forest plot usually given 30% width. example: list(n ~ .1, forest ~ 0.3)

title: Compact and minimal theme for gt tables — theme_gt_compact
text: data table object created using gt() function. table.width width table. Can specified single-length character units pixels percentage. provided single-length numeric vector, assumed value given units pixels. px() pct() helper functions can also used pass numeric values obtain values pixel percent units. ... passing additional arguments gt::tab_options() function

title: volundr package — volundr-package
text: Organize many models hypotheses, generate directed acyclic graphs models, cut variables causality-based approach analyses. package consists formulating hypothesis, testing relationships, analyzing parameters. causality-based studies, focus understanding contextualizing variables. package provides methods understand relationships outcomes, exposures, covariates.

title: volundr 0.0.0.9000
text: functions currently stable, continue similar inputs outputs. time, expansion use. hypothesize() creates individual hypotheses tested create_study() initializes data structure mapping hypothesis objects add_hypothesis() adds existing study object construct_map() creates corresponding component tables underlying study object extract_models() returns tidy raw versions analyzed study
